Macy Gray knows full well that the recording industry doesn’t seem much interested in marketing contemporary artists to a mature audience. Yet her album “The Way” (Kobalt), out this week, is music for adults, thematically as well as musically, as she intended. Pandering to no one, “The Way” works as a blend of R&B, funk and rock that updates the mix she enjoyed as a teen.

During a phone conversation last week from Chicago, where she was performing at City Winery, the 45-year-old singer-composer and mother of three said she’s not hearing much new music for people who are well into their careers and have children. Even if there were more, the industry wouldn’t get behind it. She said she pitched “The Way” to several industry executives who told her they didn’t know how to market it to grown-ups. “They dropped that whole side of the universe,” she said.
